clinicalDescription: Overview: Insomnia is a common sleep disorder in which a person has trouble falling and/or staying asleep. Insomnia can be acute or chronic in nature. Presentation: Having trouble getting to sleep or staying asleep more than 3 nights a week for 3 months is considered chronic, compromised daytime function, fatigue/malaise, behavior problems (hyperactivity, impulsivity, aggression)Assessment: Self-reported based on sleep history, sleep diary, behavioral or adjustment issues presentPlan: Insomnia may be addressed with cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) prior to medications which can be used in conjunction with CBT such as benzodiazepine receptor agonists (BZRAs, including benzodiazepines and nonbenzodiazepine BZRAs, or "z drugs"), sedating antidepressants, melatonin agonists, orexin receptor antagonists, and antipsychotics. Prognosis: Insomnia can be resolved to healthy sleep patterns if success is achieved with medication and/or CBT
